channel.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News Today: Read the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: 'Should be castrated!': Donald Trump Jr slams transgender lawyer's remarks on gender-affirming care
item.description: The Supreme Court will hear the case of 'United States v. Skrmetti', challenging Tennessee's ban on gender-affirming care for minors. This case has ignited a national debate, with lawyer Chase Strangio arguing that gender identity can emerge as early as age two, sparking strong reactions, including condemnation from Donald Trump Jr. Over 20 states have enacted similar bans.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US President-elect Donald Trump picks former PayPal CEO David Sacks as White House AI and crypto czar
item.description: Donald Trump appointed David Sacks as the White House AI and Crypto Czar. Sacks, former PayPal COO and founder of Yammer, will lead policy in these crucial tech areas, focusing on American competitiveness, free speech, and countering Big Tech bias.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Australian synagogue 'built by Holocaust survivors' targeted in fire attack, 2 injured
item.description: Two people were injured in a firebomb attack at the Adass Israel Synagogue in Ripponlea, Australia. Around 60 firefighters extinguished the blaze, which was started by two individuals using flammable liquids. Prime Minister Albanese condemned the anti-Semitic act, noting two persons of interest. The attack follows Australia's support of a UN resolution against Israel, prompting concerns about rising anti-Semitism.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'I'm a different man': Trump's defence secretary pick Pete Hegseth defends against alcohol and misconduct allegations
item.description: Pete Hegseth, facing allegations of misconduct, defended his bid for Defense Secretary, emphasizing his faith and family's influence. He addressed his mother's leaked email and discussed his conversations with senators, highlighting his commitment to Trump's vision for the Pentagon. While denying a drinking problem, Hegseth pledged abstinence if confirmed, despite potential competition from Ron DeSantis.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US President-elect Donald Trump figurine reappears in Spain's 'pooper' collection
item.description: Spanish artisans revive the tradition of crafting "caganer" figurines, featuring prominent figures like Donald Trump, mirroring his electoral success. The 2023 collection includes Emmanuel Macron, Marine Le Pen, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Vladimir Putin, Nicolas Maduro, and Javier Milei, reflecting global political dynamics.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kamala Harris again slammed for 'fake accent' as she makes first public appearance after Howard University speech
item.description: Kamala Harris reappeared at the National Black Caucus of State Legislators conference after the presidential election. Social media users criticized her for using a "fake accent," similar to accusations during her campaign. Some users also commented on her appearance, suggesting she appeared intoxicated, echoing previous online remarks.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Pakistanis can now enter Bangladesh without security clearance
item.description: Bangladesh's interim government has waived the security clearance requirement for Pakistani visa applicants, signaling a potential thaw in bilateral relations. This move follows the recent allowance of direct cargo shipments from Karachi to Chittagong, further suggesting improving ties between the two nations after a period of tension.

item.title: Bangladesh's new banknotes to exclude Mujibur's image
item.description: Bangladesh's interim government, led by Muhammad Yunus, has ordered the central bank to redesign banknotes, removing the image of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. The new currency, featuring religious imagery and symbols of the July uprising, is expected within six months.

item.title: Trump bump 2.0? Experts expect another audience surge
item.description: Donald Trump's 2024 victory is predicted to boost news engagement, similar to 2016. Experts anticipate increased subscriptions, philanthropic donations, and podcast listenership as audiences grapple with the implications. However, this surge may be tempered by news fatigue, and the long-term decline in TV viewership is expected to continue.

item.title: Asian women vote against patriarchy with their feet
item.description: Asian women, particularly in South Korea and Japan, are increasingly choosing to marry Western men. Driven by deep-rooted patriarchal expectations in their own cultures, these women seek escape from traditional gender roles and unequal pay. They view Western marriages as offering greater gender equality and a chance for companionate partnerships.

item.title: UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson and wife had been living separately for years
item.description: ​UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson's wife confirmed that there were threats delivered to her husband. But they had been living in separate homes less than a mile from each other in Maple Grove, Minnesota, though it's not known when they split. Thompson's wife is a physical therapist at a clinic in Minneapolis and in her work bio there is no mention of her husband.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: ‘Muhammad’ is the most popular boys' name in England and Wales
item.description: Muhammad topped the baby boy names list in England and Wales for the first time in 2023, surpassing Noah. Olivia remained the most popular girl's name. Pop culture, including "Barbenheimer" and musical artists, influenced name choices, while royal names declined. New entries to the top 100 include Hazel, Lilah, and Jax.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Canton

item.title: UHC CEO killer may have used a modern version of rare WWII spy gun: Report
item.description: Former NYPD inspector Paul Mauro said the killer of the UnitedHealthcare CEO does not look like a hitman because he used a very rare gun and had to fire multiple shots to kill Brian Thompson but that does not indicate that he was not a hired murderer. The gun looks like a type that has to be racked after each shot in order to shoot again making it a very rare one.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Strong earthquake strikes US' California, tsunami alert issued
item.description: A magnitude 7+ earthquake struck off the Northern California coast near Ferndale on Thursday morning, triggering a tsunami warning. Minor aftershocks followed. BART suspended transbay service, and coastal areas received urgent tsunami evacuation alerts. While over 1.3 million people likely felt the quake, a USGS yellow alert suggests minimal damage, and no casualties or property damage have been reported yet.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Elon Musk's 4-year-old son X spotted at Senate. The reason is...
item.description: Ahead of Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's meeting with the Senate and House Republicans Thursday, Elon Musk met incoming Senate Majority Leader John Thune. ​“I think we just need to make sure we spend the public’s money well," Elon Musk said as he came out of the meeting holding the hand of his four-year-old whom he took to the Senate.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Escalating Syria conflict is a 'chronic collective failure': UN chief
Bangladesh's Yunus seeks help of religious leaders in collecting accurate info about attacks on minorities
South Korea in turmoil: Protesters demand President Yoon Suk Yoon's resignation over martial law
Poland gets $4 billion US loan for defence purchases, minister says
item.description: Poland secured a $4 billion loan from the US foreign military financing program to bolster its armed forces. This adds to over $11 billion in US support for Polish armament programs, including Patriot and Apache systems. Driven by the war in Ukraine, Poland's 2024 defense spending will reach 4.1% of GDP, rising to 4.7% in 2025.

item.title: Killer of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson seen grinning in new photos
item.description: The NYPD released photos gunman who fatally shot UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson outside a Midtown Hilton. The photos, taken from a youth hostel, show the killer's face for the first time. No person has yet been nabbed in connection with the killing though bizarre clues have been found. The shell casings had words 'deny', 'defend', 'depose' written on them.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
